child.pub-comments: "Otí is often listed as an isolate, though so little is known that it should be considered unclassified. Kaufman (1994: 70) says of Otí that of the large-scale classifiers "only Greenberg dares to link this language to anything else" - Greenberg placed it in his Macro-Ge phylum. Ethnologue also classifies its Oti as belonging to "Macro-Gé," though Ribeiro (2006: 422) says "the meager available data do not support its [Otí's] inclusion into the Macro-Jê stock". (Not to be confused with Jotí [Joti, Jodi, Hotí, Hodï] of Venezuela." (Campbell and Grondona 2012: 125)

child.pub-comments: Only three words are known of Bagua. Adelaar and Muysken (2004) suggest this language cannot be classified due to lack of data. Loukotka (1968) suggests Bagua and Patagón comprise a single language, Patagón de Bagua, on his Patagón Group. Torero (2002) notes differences between Patagón and Bagua and maintains them as seperate entities, suggesting that Bagua remains unclassifiable due to insufficient data. (Campbell and Grondona 2012: 117)

child.pub-comments: "The language of the Sanavirones, once spoken near Córdova, Argentia, is 'virtually undocumented' and cannot be classified. Loukotka (1968: 48) classified Sanavirón as an isolate; there is insufficient evidence on the language to detect any connections, if any every existed (Adelaar and Muysken 2004: 502, 615)." (Campbell and Grondona 2012: 127)

child.pub-comments: There is no attestation of Caucahue, and thus is sometimes listed as an unclassified language of the south of Chile. Ethnologue lists it as a member of the Alacalufan (Qawasqaran) languages. Viegas Barros (2005: 81) suggests that this language may be related to Chono, since the Caucahues were reported to occupy the same territory and have the same cultural traits as the Chonos. (Campbell and Grondona 2012: 118)

child.pub-comments: Not to be confused with the Patagón synonym for Chon. "Torero (2002: 276-278) follows Rivet (1934: 246) in seeing a Cariban connection for this Patagón, as does Adelaar, Middle Andes, in this volume. Loukotka (1968: 221) had equated Bagua and Patagón, but Torero (2002: 278-280) notes differences in the two and maintains them as separate entities." (Campbell and Grondona 2012: 126)

child.pub-comments: "The language of the Chachapoya (Chacha) in northern Peru is extinct and extremely poorly known. Possible connections have been suggested with Hibito-Cholón, Copallén, and even the postulated -cat[e] languages. (Adelaar and Muysken 2004: 407; Torero 1989: 236-237; Loukotka 1968: 272.)" (Campbell and Grondona 2012: 119)

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle & Verónica Grondona. 2012. Classification of the indigenous languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.), The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide, 59-166. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
child.tree-val: South American Unclassified Languages: Campbell and Grondona 2012
child.pub-comments: This language is "virtually undocumented" and cannot be classified. Tovar (1961: 29) says "this language has not left remains that could give hope of a solution to the problem of classifying it". Loukotka (1968: 278) put this language in his Huarpean family. Adelaar and Muysken (2004: 615) also suggest affiliation with Huarpean. (Campbell and Grondona 2012: 120)

child.alt-names: Awano, Ahuano, Uguano, Aguanu, Santa Crucino
child.publications: Campbell, Lyle & Verónica Grondona. 2012. Classification of the indigenous languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.), The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide, 59-166. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
child.tree-val: South American Unclassified Languages: Campbell and Grondona 2012
child.pub-comments: Loutkotka (1968) classified Aguano as a member of the Chamicuro Group of is "Arawak Stock". Migliazza and Campbell (1988) list it as unclassified. Mason (1950) classifies it within "Aguano Proper". (Campbell and Grondona 2012: 116)

child.publications: Campbell, Lyle & Verónica Grondona. 2012. Classification of the indigenous languages of South America. In Lyle Campbell, Verónica Grondona & Hans Henrich Hock (eds.), The Indigenous Languages of South America: A Comprehensive Guide, 59-166. Berlin: Mouton de Gruyter.
child.tree-val: South American Unclassified Languages: Campbell and Grondona 2012
child.pub-comments: Ethnologue suggests that this language may be possibly Panoan (Pano-Takanan), the same a Marúbo, or reltated to Yanomámi (Yanomaman).
